questions.text: A 55-year-old man with a history of hypertension has renal impairment. His creatinine is 2.8 mg/dl. Urine dipstick shows blood 2+ and protein 1+. What is the most useful investigation?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

In this case, a 55-year-old man with a history of hypertension presents with renal impairment (serum creatinine 2.8 mg/dL), hematuria (blood 2+ on dipstick), and proteinuria (1+). This constellation of findings suggests a glomerular origin of kidney disease rather than a pre-renal or post-renal cause.

The presence of both hematuria and proteinuria indicates active urinary sediment, which is characteristic of glomerulonephritis or other intrinsic renal parenchymal disorders. In such settings, the most useful investigation is a renal biopsy, as it provides a definitive histological diagnosis.

It helps identify specific glomerular diseases such as IgA nephropathy, focal segmental glomerulosclerosis, membranoproliferative glomerulonephritis, or hypertensive nephrosclerosis, and plays a crucial role in determining prognosis and management.

Therefore, renal biopsy is essential when there is unexplained renal dysfunction with urinary abnormalities suggestive of glomerular disease.

Explanation of Incorrect Options:

Intravenous urogram (Option A):

This investigation involves the use of iodinated contrast, which is contraindicated in patients with impaired renal function due to the risk of contrast-induced nephropathy. It is primarily used to evaluate urothelial abnormalities or obstructive uropathy, not glomerular diseases. In this patient, it offers no etiological insight and poses unnecessary risk.

Renal ultrasound (Option B):

While it is a useful non-invasive imaging tool to assess kidney size, parenchymal echogenicity, and exclude obstruction, it does not provide information on histological changes. It can be a good initial screening tool, but in the context of active urine sediment and elevated creatinine, it is not sufficient to establish a diagnosis or guide management.

DTPA scan (Option D):

A DTPA renal scan is a nuclear medicine study used to assess renal perfusion and differential kidney function. It does not evaluate structural or histological abnormalities, and is therefore not helpful in identifying the cause of proteinuria and hematuria. It is not diagnostic in suspected glomerular disease.

questions.text: A 45-year-old man has a history of hypertension. He now presents with frank haematuria, which has been present for 6 months. His blood results show a urea of 96 mg/dl and creatinine 1.80 mg/dl. Urine shows dysmorphic RBC and 2+ protein. Serum C3 is normal. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The most likely diagnosis in this setting is IgA nephropathy (also called Berger's disease). IgA nephropathy is the most common primary glomerulonephritis worldwide and typically presents in young to middle-aged adults. It can follow infections, but unlike post-streptococcal glomerulonephritis, complement levels are normal in IgA nephropathy.

Key supporting features for IgA nephropathy:

  • Frank haematuria (often recurrent, and may be persistent in chronic cases)
  • Microscopic findings: Dysmorphic RBCs suggest a glomerular origin of bleeding
  • Mild to moderate proteinuria (2+)
  • Normal complement levels (C3 is normal) - a very important clue
  • Often associated with hypertension and mild renal dysfunction in later stages

Explanation of Incorrect Options:

Focal segmental glomerulosclerosis (Option A):

  • Presents more with nephrotic syndrome (heavy proteinuria, edema) than haematuria
  • Dysmorphic RBCs and persistent haematuria are not typical presenting features

Acute tubular necrosis (Option C):

  • Associated with acute kidney injury, often following ischemia or toxins
  • Urine typically shows granular ("muddy brown") casts, not dysmorphic RBCs
  • Haematuria and proteinuria are not prominent features

Minimal change disease (Option D):

  • Primarily a nephrotic syndrome, especially in children
  • Would show massive proteinuria, but not haematuria or dysmorphic RBCs

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman presents with dipstick-positive haematuria. Her blood tests reveal a urea of 150 mg/dl and creatinine of 2.9 mg/dl. Which of the following most strongly suggests post-streptococcal glomerulonephritis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Post-streptococcal glomerulonephritis (PSGN) is a classic example of a post-infectious glomerulonephritis, most often occurring after an infection with group A β-hemolytic streptococcus. It typically follows a latent period of 1-3 weeks after the initial infection, which may be a sore throat (pharyngitis) or skin infection (impetigo).

In this case, the patient presents with:

  • Hematuria (dipstick positive)
  • Elevated urea (150 mg/dL) and creatinine (2.9 mg/dL) → suggest renal dysfunction

The history of a sore throat 10 days prior aligns well with the typical latent period (7-21 days) for PSGN, making it the most specific and supportive finding in favour of this diagnosis among the options given.

Explanation of Incorrect Options:

History of previous attacks (Option A):

PSGN is usually a self-limiting, one-time illness, especially in children. Recurrent episodes are not common, and a history of previous attacks would not specifically support a diagnosis of PSGN in the current setting.

Papilledema (Option B):

Papilledema is a sign of raised intracranial pressure, which can occasionally be seen in hypertensive emergencies associated with renal failure, but it is not specific to PSGN. It indicates end-organ damage from hypertension but not the underlying cause.

Complete anuria (Option D):

Anuria is uncommon in PSGN and is more characteristic of rapidly progressive glomerulonephritis (RPGN) or acute tubular necrosis. PSGN usually presents with oliguria, not a complete absence of urine output.

questions.text: A 15-year-old boy presents with a non-blanching rash over his shins and a swollen knee. He has noticed haematuria. Blood tests show a urea of 72 mg/dl and a Creatinine of 3 mg/dl. Urine dipstick shows: blood +++, protein +. What is the renal biopsy likely to show?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

This 15-year-old boy presents with a non-blanching rash on the shins, joint swelling, and hematuria-a classic triad suggestive of Henoch-Schönlein Purpura (HSP), now more accurately referred to as IgA vasculitis. His renal function is impaired (urea 72 mg/dL, creatinine 3 mg/dL), and the urinalysis shows significant hematuria (+++) and proteinuria (+), indicating renal involvement, which is a known complication of IgA vasculitis.

On renal biopsy, the characteristic finding in HSP nephritis is mesangial deposition of IgA-containing immune complexes, which is identical to the pattern seen in IgA nephropathy (Berger's disease). The deposition leads to mesangial proliferation and can vary in severity, ranging from minimal change to crescentic glomerulonephritis, depending on the disease stage and severity.

Explanation of Incorrect options:

Tubular necrosis (Option A):

Seen in acute tubular injury, often due to ischemia, toxins, or sepsis. It does not present with purpura or hematuria as dominant features, and histology would show necrotic tubular epithelial cells, not glomerular IgA deposits.

Podocyte fusion (Option B):

Characteristics of minimal change disease and focal segmental glomerulosclerosis. It typically causes nephrotic syndrome, with heavy proteinuria, minimal hematuria, and normal renal function early on. It is not associated with systemic symptoms like rash or joint involvement.

Thickening of basement membranes (Option D):

Seen in membranous nephropathy or diabetic nephropathy. These conditions are more common in adults and are associated with nephrotic syndrome, not purpura, arthritis, or gross hematuria. Thickened basement membranes would be visualised on electron microscopy or special stains.

questions.text: A 30-year-old lady has haematuria on the dipstick and was referred by the GP for further investigation. She eventually has a renal biopsy, which shows mesangial hypercellularity with IgA deposition. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

This 30-year-old woman presents with hematuria and has a renal biopsy showing mesangial hypercellularity with IgA deposition, which is the hallmark of IgA nephropathy (also known as Berger's disease). It is the most common primary glomerulonephritis worldwide, particularly in young adults.

Key features of IgA nephropathy:

  • Typically presents with episodic hematuria, often coinciding with upper respiratory tract infections("synpharyngitic hematuria").
  • Biopsy findings: Mesangial proliferation and dominant IgA deposition on immunofluorescence.
  • Serum complement levels (C3 and C4) are usually normal, helping to distinguish it from other complement-mediated nephritides.
  • It can range from benign hematuria to progressive renal disease.

Explanation of Incorrect Options:

Mesangiocapillary glomerulonephritis (Option A):

Characterised by both mesangial and endocapillary proliferation, often with "tram-track" appearance and low C3 levels. It shows C3 deposition more prominently than IgA.

HIV nephropathy (Option C):

Typically shows collapsing focal segmental glomerulosclerosis (FSGS) on biopsy, not IgA deposition. It often presents with proteinuria and rapidly progressive renal failure.

Nephrotic syndrome (Option D):

This is a clinical syndrome, not a specific diagnosis. It is characterised by proteinuria >3.5 g/day, hypoalbuminemia, hyperlipidemia, and oedema. While IgA nephropathy may sometimes present with nephrotic-range proteinuria, the question gives no such clinical details.

questions.text: A 70-year-old male with a 3-month history of constitutional symptoms including weight loss, night sweats, fatigue, and malaise presents with rapidly progressive acute renal failure, haemoptysis and diffuse bilateral pulmonary infiltrates. Biopsy demonstrates a pauci-immune focal segmental proliferative, necrotising and sclerosing glomerulonephritis with crescent formation and a superimposed necrotising and granulomatous arteritis involving small intrarenal arteries. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The clinical presentation, combined with the biopsy findings, is most consistent with Wegener's granulomatosis. This condition is a form of pauci-immune small vessel vasculitis, strongly associated with granulomatous inflammation involving the respiratory tract and rapidly progressive glomerulonephritis. The presence of constitutional symptoms, pulmonary haemorrhage, and acute renal failure points toward a systemic vasculitic process.

The biopsy showing pauci-immune necrotising glomerulonephritis with crescents, along with necrotising granulomatous arteritis, is classic for GPA. The hallmark of this disease is the combination of granulomatous inflammation with necrotising vasculitis affecting small to medium vessels, particularly in the kidneys and lungs.

The absence of significant immune deposits on immunofluorescence (pauci-immune) helps distinguish it from immune-complex-mediated conditions like post-streptococcal glomerulonephritis.

Explanation of Incorrect Options:

Polyarteritis Nodosa (Option A):

Polyarteritis nodosa (PAN) is a medium-sized vessel vasculitis that typically spares the lungs, which is a key point against this diagnosis. While PAN can cause renal infarctions and hypertension, it does not cause glomerulonephritis. Additionally, the absence of pulmonary involvement in PAN makes it an unlikely cause in a patient with diffuse pulmonary infiltrates and haemoptysis, both of which are present in this case.

Goodpasture Syndrome (Option B):
Goodpasture's syndrome is characterised by anti-GBM antibody-mediated disease, causing pulmonary haemorrhage and glomerulonephritis. However, the renal biopsy in Goodpasture's typically shows linear IgG deposition along the basement membrane on immunofluorescence. This case is described as pauci-immune, which means there is minimal or no immune complex deposition, making Goodpasture's unlikely. Additionally, granulomatous arteritis is not a feature of Goodpasture syndrome.

Post-streptococcal Glomerulonephritis (Option C):

This condition typically follows a streptococcal infection, especially in children or young adults, and presents with nephritic syndrome. Biopsy in post-streptococcal GN shows immune complex deposition, especially subepithelial 'hump'-like deposits, and low complement levels. Again, the biopsy here is pauci-immune and shows granulomatous inflammation, neither of which is a feature of post-streptococcal GN.

questions.text: A 45-year-old man feels unwell following a sore throat and cough. He has a blood pressure of 170/90 mm Hg. The dipstick of his urine reveals blood ++ and protein ++. His blood tests show: Hb 10.5 g/dl, MCV 85 fl, WBC 7000/mm3, platelets 200000/mm3, sodium 135 mmol/l, potassium 4.2 mmol/l, urea 50 mmol/l, creatinine 2.6 mg/dl, ALT 25 (5-35) U/l, AST 35 (A-35) U/l, ALP 75 (20-120) U/l, GGT 30 (D-35) U/l, Bilirubin 0.8 mg/dl, Albumin 3.8 (3.5-5) g/dl, calcium 8 mg/dl, phosphate 4.5 mg/dl. C3 - 0.5 g/L (0.8 - 1.6), C4 - 0.17 g/L (0.15 - 0.55). C3 nephritic factor is positive. Ultrasound scan of his kidneys reveals the left kidney of 8.5 cm and the right kidney of 9.3 cm. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

This 45-year-old man presents with hypertension, hematuria, proteinuria, and renal impairment (creatinine 2.6 mg/dL) following a sore throat and cough. While a post-infectious glomerulonephritis is a consideration, the persistent renal dysfunction, markedly low C3 level, and the presence of C3 nephritic factor point towards MPGN. MPGN (also known as membranoproliferative GN) is classically associated with:

  • Hypocomplementemia, particularly low C3 with normal or near-normal C4, is due to alternative complement pathway activation.
  • C3 nephritic factor, an autoantibody that stabilises C3 convertase, is a hallmark of type II MPGN (dense deposit disease).
  • Renal biopsy typically reveals mesangial and endocapillary proliferation, and a tram-track appearance on light microscopy.

Explanation of Incorrect Options:

Post-streptococcal glomerulonephritis (Option A): May present similarly but typically resolves within weeks. Also, C3 usually returns to normal within 6-8 weeks, and C3 nephritic factor is not seen.

Acute tubular necrosis (Option B): Usually occurs due to ischemia or toxins and is characterised by granular casts, normal complement levels, and absence of significant proteinuria or hematuria on dipstick.

Membranous nephropathy (Option C): Presents with nephrotic-range proteinuria, normal complement levels, and lacks hematuria and hypertension in early stages.

questions.text: A 70-year-old man with no previous past medical history presents with a BP of 180/100 mm Hg, frothy urine and peripheral oedema. There is 1+ blood and 3+ protein on urinalysis. 24-hour protein loss is 5 grams. Plasma albumin is 2.5 g/dL. Plasma C3 is 0.1 (low). Plasma creatinine is 1.80 mg/dl. A renal biopsy is performed. ANA is negative. ESR is 110. Which of the following is most likely to be found on the biopsy?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

This 70-year-old man presents with new-onset hypertension (BP 180/100 mmHg), frothy urine, peripheral oedema, and heavy proteinuria (5 grams/day), all of which point toward nephrotic syndrome. Additionally, there is 1+ hematuria and an elevated creatinine (1.8 mg/dL), suggesting glomerular involvement with some degree of renal impairment.

The low serum albumin (2.5 g/dL) confirms nephrotic-range protein loss, and the markedly low complement C3 (0.1)is a key diagnostic clue. Among glomerular diseases, mesangiocapillary glomerulonephritis (MPGN)-also known as membranoproliferative glomerulonephritis-is classically associated with low complement levels, particularly hypo-C3emia, due to persistent activation of the alternative complement pathway. The very high ESR (110 mm/hr) further suggests an active inflammatory or immune-mediated process.

MPGN presents with a mixed nephrotic-nephritic picture: proteinuria (often >3.5 g/day), hematuria, impaired renal function, and low complement levels. It can be idiopathic (primary) or secondary to infections (e.g., HCV), autoimmune diseases, or paraproteinemias. The patient's negative ANA argues against lupus nephritis, and his age and presentation without prior history make idiopathic or infection-associated MPGN more likely.

Explanation of Incorrect Options:

Minimal change glomerulonephritis (Option A):

Typically presents with pure nephrotic syndrome, especially in children and young adults. It is not associated with hematuria, low complement levels, or elevated ESR, and renal function is usually preserved. It is rare in the elderly.

IgA nephropathy (Option C):

Usually presents with recurrent hematuria, often following upper respiratory tract infections, and may have mild proteinuria, but nephrotic-range proteinuria and low C3 are uncommon. Complement levels are usually normal in IgA nephropathy.

Post-streptococcal glomerulonephritis (Option D):

It can present with low C3, but usually occurs in children or young adults, and typically shows a nephritic picture(hematuria, red cell casts, hypertension), not predominant nephrotic syndrome. Also, the latent period after a sore throat/skin infection is a key historical clue, which is not present here.

questions.text: A 20-year-old patient complains of ankle swelling and breathlessness. Her CXR shows pleural effusions. Blood tests show: urea 17 mg/dl, creatinine 0.90 mg/dl, sodium 138 mmol/l, potassium 4.2 mmol/l/, alanine transferase 20 U/L/, bilirubin 0.9 mg/d, albumin 2 gm/dl, total cholesterol 340 mg/dl. What is the next best investigation?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

In a young patient presenting with ankle swelling, breathlessness, pleural effusions, and laboratory findings of hypoalbuminemia (albumin 2 g/dL) and marked hypercholesterolemia (total cholesterol 340 mg/dL)-with normal renal and liver function tests-the most likely clinical diagnosis is nephrotic syndrome.

  • This condition is characterised by heavy proteinuria, hypoalbuminemia, oedema, and hyperlipidemia. The presence of these classic features makes nephrotic syndrome the most probable aetiology.
  • Before proceeding to more advanced investigations such as serological markers or renal biopsy, it is essential to confirm the presence of proteinuria, which is the defining feature of nephrotic syndrome. Therefore, the next best investigation is a urinary protein estimation, either via 24-hour urine protein collection or spot urine protein-to-creatinine ratio, to quantify the degree of protein loss and confirm the diagnosis.
  • This is a simple, non-invasive, and essential first step in the diagnostic pathway. Once nephrotic-range proteinuria is established, further investigations such as autoantibody testing or renal biopsy may be considered based on the clinical context.

Explanation of Incorrect Options:

Ultrasound of liver (Option A):

While pleural effusion and hypoalbuminemia can occur in chronic liver disease, the patient has normal liver enzymes and bilirubin, and there's no mention of stigmata of liver disease. The high cholesterol and proteinuria are much more suggestive of a renal cause.

Antinuclear antibody (Option B):

ANA is a useful test for autoimmune diseases such as SLE, which can cause nephrotic syndrome. However, this is a second-line test after confirming proteinuria. It does not replace the need to first establish the presence of nephrotic-range proteinuria.

Renal biopsy (Option D):

Renal biopsy is an invasive test and is not the immediate next step unless there's confirmed significant proteinuria and the cause is unclear or requires histological classification. It is not done before confirming nephrotic syndrome.

questions.text: Which one of the following is the commonest cause of nephrotic syndrome in adults?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Focal segmental glomerulosclerosis (FSGS) is currently recognised as the most common cause of nephrotic syndrome in adults in many parts of the world, including the United States and several developing countries. It is characterised by sclerosis (scarring) in parts (segmental) of some (focal) glomeruli. FSGS may be primary (idiopathic)or secondary to factors such as obesity, HIV infection, heroin use, or reduced renal mass.

Clinical features typically include:

  • Heavy proteinuria (>3.5 g/day)
  • Hypoalbuminemia
  • Edema
  • Often associated with hypertension and reduced renal function

Diagnosis is confirmed by renal biopsy, and treatment typically involves corticosteroids or immunosuppressants, though response may be limited in some cases, especially in secondary FSGS.

Explanation of Incorrect Options:

Minimal change glomerulonephritis (Option A):

Although this is the most common cause of nephrotic syndrome in children, it accounts for only about 10–15% of adult cases. In adults, it may be associated with NSAID use, Hodgkin lymphoma, or idiopathic. Light microscopy appears normal, hence the name, but electron microscopy shows podocyte foot process effacement.

Membranoproliferative glomerulonephritis (Option C):

This is a less common cause of nephrotic syndrome in adults. It presents more frequently with a mixed nephritic-nephrotic picture and is associated with chronic infections (e.g., HCV), immune complex disorders, or complement dysregulation.

Membranous nephropathy (Option D):

This is a common cause of nephrotic syndrome in adults, especially in the elderly, but not the most common overall. It is characterised by subepithelial immune complex deposition and is associated with malignancies, autoimmune diseases, infections, and drugs. The hallmark of a biopsy is a spike and dome appearance on a silver stain.

questions.text: A 50-year-old woman who is morbidly obese presents with a plasma creatinine of 2.8 mg/dl. Which form of disease is likely?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

This 50-year-old woman is described as morbidly obese with a significantly elevated serum creatinine of 2.8 mg/dL, indicating chronic kidney disease. Among glomerular diseases, Focal Segmental Glomerulosclerosis (FSGS) is strongly associated with obesity and is the most likely diagnosis in this context.

Obesity-associated FSGS is a well-recognised secondary form of FSGS. The pathophysiology involves:

  • Hyperfiltration injury due to increased body mass
  • Glomerular hypertrophy and segmental sclerosis
  • Often, gradual onset proteinuria, which may or may not reach the nephrotic range
  • Progressive decline in renal function

The condition is typically insidious, with mild to moderate proteinuria, but over time can lead to renal insufficiency, especially if risk factors like obesity, hypertension, or diabetes are uncontrolled.

Explanation of Incorrect Options:

Renal tubular acidosis (Option A):

This is a disorder of acid-base regulation in the renal tubules and typically presents with normal anion gap metabolic acidosis. It does not cause significant elevation in serum creatinine early on and is not characteristically linked to obesity.

Nephritic syndrome (Option C):

This presents with hematuria, hypertension, oliguria, and mild proteinuria, and typically has a more acute onset. It is not characteristically associated with obesity and would not usually cause this level of creatinine elevation without other prominent features.

Membranous glomerulonephritis (Option D):

While this is a common cause of nephrotic syndrome in adults, it is not particularly associated with obesity. It is more often linked to autoimmune disease, malignancy, or infections. The question points to a metabolic stress-related glomerular disease, making FSGS more likely.

questions.text: A 30-year-old intravenous drug user who is HIV positive presents with oedematous ankles and breathlessness. There is no history of diabetes. He has a creatinine of 1.4 mg/dl. AST is 25 U/l, ALP is 120 U/l, and albumin is 2.5 g/dl. A 24-hour urine protein is 5.5g in total. Which of the following is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

This 30-year-old HIV-positive intravenous drug user presents with oedema, breathlessness, and heavy proteinuria(5.5 g/day) with hypoalbuminemia (2.5 g/dl)—all pointing toward a nephrotic syndrome. The most likely renal pathology in HIV patients presenting with nephrotic-range proteinuria is Focal Segmental Glomerulosclerosis (FSGS), particularly the collapsing variant, which is strongly associated with HIV-associated nephropathy (HIVAN).

Key features that support FSGS in this patient:

  • HIV-positive status
  • IV drug use (a known risk factor for HIV and kidney damage)
  • Nephrotic-range proteinuria (>3.5 g/day)
  • Low albumin (2.5 g/dl), which explains the oedema
  • Creatinine is slightly elevated (1.4 mg/dl), indicating early renal dysfunction

Explanation of incorrect options:

Minimal change nephropathy (Option B):

  • More common in children
  • In adults, it causes nephrotic syndrome but is not associated with HIV
  • Biopsy in minimal change disease is usually normal under light microscopy, unlike FSGS, which shows segmental sclerosis

Membranoproliferative glomerulonephritis (Option C):

  • More associated with hepatitis B/C or chronic infections
  • Typically shows mixed nephritic-nephrotic features, low complement levels, and hematuria, which are not reported here

Nephritic syndrome (Option D):

  • Characterised by hematuria, hypertension, mild to moderate proteinuria, and active urine sediment
  • This patient has nephrotic syndrome, not nephritic

questions.text: A 10-year-old boy presents with generalised oedema. There was no relevant past medical history. Investigations revealed: Creatinine 0.65 mg/dl, Albumin 2 g/dl, 24-hour urine protein excretion 3.2 g. Ultrasound scan shows normal renal size. Renal biopsy was performed, which was normal by light microscopy and showed minimal IgM deposit on IF. Which of the following should the patient be treated with initially?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

A 10-year-old boy presents with generalised oedema, hypoalbuminemia (2 g/dL), and nephrotic-range proteinuria (3.2 g/day) with normal renal function (creatinine 0.65 mg/dL). These features are diagnostic of nephrotic syndrome. In children, the most common cause of nephrotic syndrome is Minimal Change Disease (MCD), accounting for nearly 80-90% of cases. Renal biopsy in MCD is typically normal on light microscopy, and immunofluorescence may show minimal or no immune deposits, which is exactly the finding described here (minimal IgM on IF). This pattern strongly supports the diagnosis of MCD.

The first-line treatment for MCD is oral corticosteroids, specifically prednisolone, because children with MCD show an excellent and rapid response to steroid therapy. This response not only confirms the diagnosis but also leads to complete remission in most cases. Hence, steroid therapy is both diagnostic and therapeutic in such presentations.

Explanation of Incorrect Options:

Cyclophosphamide (Option A):

An immunosuppressive agent used in frequently relapsing or steroid-dependent nephrotic syndrome. It is not first-line therapy for initial presentation.

Peritoneal dialysis (Option B):

Not indicated here as the child has normal renal function. Dialysis is reserved for renal failure, which is absent in this case.

Thiazides (Option C):

These diuretics can be used for symptomatic control of oedema, but they do not address the underlying immune mechanism and are not a definitive treatment. Prednisolone remains the primary therapy.

choices.text: Reduced concentration of Von Willebrand's factor

questions.text: A 60-year-old woman has bilateral swollen calves and ankles, with the left calf more painful and swollen. A 24-hr urine protein was 8g/day. Which could explain these findings?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

This patient's clinical picture is consistent with nephrotic syndrome, suggested by massive proteinuria (8 g/day) and bilateral leg oedema, especially with asymmetry and pain, raising suspicion for deep vein thrombosis (DVT).

In nephrotic syndrome, there's urinary loss of antithrombin III, an important endogenous anticoagulant. This reduction in antithrombin III activity leads to a hypercoagulable state, making patients prone to venous thromboembolism, especially DVT and renal vein thrombosis.

Explanation of Incorrect Options:

Factor VIII deficiency (Option A):

This is the cause of Haemophilia A, a bleeding disorder, not a clotting disorder. Patients with Factor VIII deficiency are at risk of bleeding, not thrombosis. This does not explain the DVT or nephrotic proteinuria.

Reduced concentration of Von Willebrand's factor (Option B):

Von Willebrand's factor is essential for platelet adhesion. Reduced levels cause Von Willebrand disease, leading to mucocutaneous bleeding, not thrombosis. Again, this would not lead to swelling from clot formation.

Reduced D-dimer levels (Option C):

D-dimer is a fibrin degradation product, elevated in active thrombosis. A reduction would not be expected in DVT. Moreover, D-dimer is a marker, not a cause, so this does not explain the patient’s symptoms.

choices.text: IgM deposits around the renal tubules

questions.text: A 40-year-old man has proteinuria with a dipstick demonstrating +++ of protein. He has a history of diabetes and albumin of 2.6 g/dl. A physician suspects membranous glomerulonephritis. Which of the following is likely to support this diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

In a 40-year-old diabetic man presenting with heavy proteinuria (+++), hypoalbuminemia (albumin 2.6 g/dl), and a suspected diagnosis of membranous glomerulonephritis (MGN), the presence of renal vein thrombosis (RVT)strongly supports the diagnosis.

Membranous nephropathy is one of the most common causes of nephrotic syndrome in adults, and is well known to be associated with an increased risk of thrombotic complications, particularly renal vein thrombosis. This hypercoagulable state is due to multiple factors seen in nephrotic syndrome, such as:

  • Loss of antithrombin III in urine
  • Hyperfibrinogenemia
  • Hemoconcentration
  • Increased platelet aggregability

Renal vein thrombosis, while it may occur with other nephrotic conditions, is classically and most frequently associated with membranous nephropathy. It may present acutely with flank pain and hematuria or be asymptomatic and discovered on imaging.

Explanation of Incorrect Options:

Selective proteinuria (Option A):

This is more characteristic of minimal change disease, not membranous glomerulonephritis. MGN typically shows non-selective proteinuria, with both albumin and other proteins lost.

IgM deposits around the renal tubules (Option B):

This is not a characteristic finding of membranous glomerulonephritis. MGN typically shows granular deposits of IgG and complement (C3) along the glomerular basement membrane on immunofluorescence and electron-dense subepithelial deposits on EM.

Recent streptococcal throat infection (Option C):

Suggestive of post-streptococcal glomerulonephritis, a nephritic syndrome more commonly seen in children, characterised by hematuria, low complement levels, and hypertension, not heavy proteinuria and hypoalbuminemia as seen here.

choices.text: Mesangial IgA staining and proliferative glomerulonephritis
Subendothelial deposits seen as humps with focal glomerulonephritis
Deposition of IgA, IgG, IgM and complements with proliferative glomerulonephritis
Focal or diffuse glomerular necrosis with crescents and linear IgG deposits along the basement membrane in IF.

questions.text: A 40-year-old woman has a history of Raynaud's phenomenon, stiffness in the hands, butterfly rash on her face and arthralgia. She has a blood pressure of 175/90 mmHg. Urine dipstick shows protein ++ and blood +. Blood tests reveal a creatinine of 1.6 mg/dl, ESR 60 mm/hour and positive ANA 1/160 titres. Which of the following is most likely to be the result of the renal biopsy?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Given the systemic features, positive ANA, and renal involvement in the form of proteinuria, hematuria, and elevated creatinine, the diagnosis is Lupus Nephritis. The most common and serious renal lesion in lupus nephritis is diffuse proliferative glomerulonephritis (Class IV), characterised on biopsy by immune complex deposition and proliferation of glomerular cells. Immunofluorescence typically shows full-house staining, meaning deposits of IgA, IgG, IgM, C3, and C1q in the glomeruli.


Explanation of Incorrect Options:

Mesangial IgA staining and proliferative glomerulonephritis (Option A): 

This pattern is typical of IgA nephropathy (Berger’s disease), which usually presents with recurrent hematuria, especially post-infectiously. It is not associated with SLE, and ANA would not be positive.

Subendothelial deposits seen as humps with focal glomerulonephritis (Option B):
This is characteristic of post-streptococcal glomerulonephritis, where electron microscopy shows "hump-like" subepithelial deposits. It is typically seen in children or young adults following a streptococcal infection and not in the autoimmune context of SLE.

Focal or diffuse glomerular necrosis with crescents and linear IgG deposits along the basement membrane (Option D):
This is seen in Goodpasture’s syndrome (anti-GBM disease). The hallmark finding is linear IgG staining on immunofluorescence, which is not typical of SLE. Goodpasture's often presents with pulmonary haemorrhage and rapidly progressive glomerulonephritis, which are not features in this case.

questions.text: A 45-year-old man presents with recurrent sinusitis for over a year and occasionally notices a rash on his chest. Routine blood tests show that he has a serum urea of 84 mg/dl and creatinine of 1.8 mg/dl. Which of the following is the most likely?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

This 45-year-old man presents with a triad of symptoms that strongly suggest systemic vasculitis.

Together, these findings are classically seen in granulomatosis with polyangiitis (GPA), previously called Wegener's granulomatosis, a type of ANCA-associated vasculitis. GPA typically involves:

  • Upper respiratory tract (sinusitis, nasal ulcers)
  • Lower respiratory tract (cough, hemoptysis)
  • Kidneys (rapidly progressive glomerulonephritis)
  • Skin lesions (palpable purpura, ulcers)

Explanation of Incorrect Options:

Minimal change nephropathy (Option A):

  • Presents with nephrotic syndrome (massive proteinuria, oedema)
  • Not associated with sinusitis or rash
  • Kidney function is usually normal initially

Membranous glomerulonephritis (Option C):

  • Causes nephrotic syndrome, not systemic symptoms
  • No upper respiratory or skin involvement

Goodpasture's syndrome (Option D):

  • Involves the lungs and kidneys, but not sinusitis or rash
  • Associated with hemoptysis and hematuria, and anti-GBM antibodies

questions.text: A 35-year-old lady with SLE presents with significant proteinuria and hypoalbuminemia. A renal biopsy confirms diffuse proliferative glomerulonephritis(WHO Class IV). Which of the following treatment regimes is recommended?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

This patient has Systemic Lupus Erythematosus (SLE) with nephrotic-range proteinuria and hypoalbuminemia, which are features of lupus nephritis. A renal biopsy confirms WHO Class IV (diffuse proliferative glomerulonephritis)-the most severe and common form of lupus nephritis. It involves >50% of glomeruli and often presents with hematuria, proteinuria, hypertension, and renal insufficiency.

The recommended treatment for Class IV lupus nephritis is aggressive immunosuppression to prevent irreversible renal damage. The best regimen includes high-dose corticosteroids (prednisolone) to control inflammation and intravenous cyclophosphamide, a cytotoxic agent that suppresses the autoimmune process.

Explanation of Incorrect Options:

Prednisolone alone (Option A):

While steroids are essential, monotherapy is insufficient for Class IV lupus nephritis due to the aggressive nature of glomerular inflammation. Without a cytotoxic agent, the risk of progression to ESRD remains high.

Azathioprine alone (Option B):

Azathioprine is an immunosuppressant, but it's used mostly for maintenance therapy, not for induction in severe lupus nephritis. It's not potent enough to control active Class IV disease when used alone.

Azathioprine & Methotrexate (Option C):

This combination is used in rheumatologic manifestations of SLE (e.g., arthritis, skin involvement), but not for renal disease. Methotrexate has limited efficacy and potential nephrotoxicity, making it inappropriate in lupus nephritis.

questions.text: A 55-year-old man has developed nephrotic syndrome recently. His investigations show an albumin of 2.0 g/dL, Total cholesterol of 347 mg/dl, 24-hour urine reveals 4.5g protein excretion. A renal biopsy shows focal segmental glomerulosclerosis. Which one of the following is most likely to preserve renal function?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

This patient has classic features of nephrotic syndrome-hypoalbuminemia (2.0 g/dL), hypercholesterolemia (347 mg/dL), and proteinuria >3.5 g/day (4.5g/24hr). The renal biopsy confirms Focal Segmental Glomerulosclerosis (FSGS), a primary glomerular disease known to cause progressive renal dysfunction if left untreated.

The most effective strategy to preserve renal function in FSGS is the use of ACE inhibitors, such as Lisinopril. ACE inhibitors reduce intraglomerular pressure, thereby decreasing proteinuria and slowing the progression of chronic kidney disease (CKD). They also offer renoprotective benefits independent of blood pressure control.

Explanation of Incorrect Options:

(A) Bendrofluazide:

This is a thiazide diuretic, useful for controlling oedema in nephrotic syndrome, but it does not reduce proteinuria or directly preserve renal function. It may be used symptomatically but is not disease-modifying in FSGS.

(B) Salt restriction:

While salt restriction helps in managing oedema and hypertension, it has no direct impact on glomerular damage or disease progression. It is an important supportive measure, but not sufficient alone to preserve renal function.

(D) Atorvastatin:

This statin is appropriate for treating hyperlipidemia, which is part of nephrotic syndrome. However, it does not reduce proteinuria or have direct renoprotective effects in glomerular disease like FSGS. It's useful for cardiovascular risk management, not for renal preservation.

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman presented with a history of nephrotic syndrome diagnosed when she was 4 years old. There was no family history of renal disease. An initial renal biopsy performed showed minimal-change disease. She was treated with steroids and was determined to be steroid-dependent. Subsequent trials of cyclosporine and cyclophosphamide failed to improve her condition, and she was referred for additional evaluation. She has a second renal biopsy. Light microscopic examination showed a patchy but striking vacuolar change in the renal tubular cells, with large nodular aggregates of foamy cells. Intracellular accumulation of several glycosphingolipids was suspected. Which one of the following is likely?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The most likely diagnosis in this case is Anderson-Fabry disease, a rare X-linked lysosomal storage disorder caused by a deficiency of the enzyme α-galactosidase A. This leads to the accumulation of glycosphingolipids, particularly globotriaosylceramide (Gb3), within various cells, including renal tubular cells and podocytes.

In this patient, the early-onset nephrotic syndrome, steroid-dependence, and resistance to immunosuppressants, followed by vacuolar changes in the renal tubules and foamy cell aggregates on biopsy, are classic indicators of Fabry nephropathy. The foamy appearance is due to the lysosomal storage of glycolipids, and the vacuolated cytoplasm seen under light microscopy is characteristic of lipid accumulation.

Renal involvement in Fabry disease can mimic minimal change disease or FSGS early in life but progresses with renal dysfunction and proteinuria. A high index of suspicion is required when there's recurrent nephrotic syndrome not responding to typical treatments.

Angiokeratoma corporis diffusum

Explanation of Incorrect Options:

(A) Tuberculosis:

Renal tuberculosis typically causes sterile pyuria, hematuria, and caseating granulomas on biopsy, not foamy cells or lipid accumulation. It is not consistent with the long-standing nephrotic picture described here.

(B) Diabetic nephropathy:

This typically presents in patients with a history of diabetes mellitus, which this patient does not have. Biopsy usually shows nodular glomerulosclerosis (Kimmelstiel-Wilson nodules), not foamy tubular cells or glycosphingolipid accumulation.

Although some types may affect the kidney, they usually present with hepatomegaly, hypoglycemia, or lactic acidosis in infancy or childhood. Renal pathology is more often glycogen deposition, not glycosphingolipids, and the characteristic foamy cell aggregates are not typical.
